skills.name: Interpret the numbers in a single stem and leaf diagram
Interpret the numbers in a back-to-back stem and leaf diagram
Calculate the mode from a single stem and leaf diagram

explanations.A: I think you have tried to count all of the numbers in the stem. We are only interested in the values that are greater than 20
explanations.B: I think you have included the 2 people who were 20 years old, but we wanted those who were over 20.
explanations.D: I think you have misread the question and counted the people who are 30 or over. Read the question carefully

explanations.A: There are 6 people in the 20 leaf, 4 in the 30 leaf and 5 in the 40 leaf, which makes 15 people aged over to, and including, 20. However, one of those people is aged 20, so they are not over 20 and are not counted. This gives 14 people in total.
explanations.B: I think you have included the person who is 20 years old, but we wanted those who were over 20.
explanations.C: I think you have included the numbers in the stem when counting. In order to find the total number of people we just count the values in each leaf
explanations.D: I think you have misread the question and counted the people who are 30 or over. Read the question carefully

explanations.A: 42 appears 3 times, so it is the mode.
explanations.B: I think you may have picked 1 as it is the stem with the most pieces of data. However, these pieces of data do not represent the same age. They mean 11, 12, 12, 13, 13 and 15. Is there one age in the whole stem and leaf diagram that appears the most?
explanations.C: There are 2 people who are aged 12, but if you continue to look at the data there are also 2 people aged 13. Can you find an age which is shared by more than 2 people?
explanations.D: You have seen that 2 is the most common digit in the leaf parts, but remember these do not represent an age of 2. The first 2 is in the 1 stem so represents someone who is 12 years old. Do all 2s represent someone who is 12? We must use the key and consider both the stem and the leaf when finding the mode.

explanations.A: I think you might have interpreted the stem and leaf diagram incorrectly. There are 3 twos in the 1 stem so this does represent our mode, but we need to look at the key to work out what age this represents.
explanations.B: 42 appears twice, but there are 2 other ages that appear twice and one other age that appears 3 times! Can you find the age that appears 3 times?
explanations.C: The age that appears most often is 12, which appears three times.
explanations.D: 2 is the most common digit in our diagram, but we need to look at the key to work out what age this represents.

explanations.A: We need to also look at the number in the stem. Use the key to help.
explanations.B: Not quite. Use the key to help. What place value does the stem have?
explanations.C: The digit on the stem is 6 and the digit on the leaf is 9. The key tells us that putting these together gives a score of 69%.
explanations.D: Nearly. Read the key carefully. What place value does the stem have?

explanations.A: The digit on the stem is 8 and the digit on the leaf is 3. The key tells us that putting these together gives a score of 83%.
explanations.B: Nearly. Read the key carefully. What place value does the stem have?
explanations.C: We need to also look at the number in the stem. Use the key to help.
explanations.D: Not quite. Use the key to help. What place value does the stem have?

explanations.A: The largest digit on the bottom leaf is 4 which has a corresponding stem digit of 9. Putting these together according to the key gives 94%
explanations.B: You have given the lowest score. Look at the key to see how the stem and leaf values are interpreted
explanations.C: You have chosen the highest value, but interpreted it incorrectly. Use the key to help.
explanations.D: You have given the lowest score in the highest group. Look again at the leaf numbers next to the 9 in the stem. Which if these is largest?

explanations.A: There is only one digit on the top leaf, so this must be the lowest score. The stem number is 5 and the leaf number is 6, which the key tells us corresponds to a score of 56%.
explanations.B: You have given the highest score. Look at the key to see how the stem and leaf values are interpreted
explanations.C: You have chosen the lowest value, but interpreted it incorrectly. Use the key to help.
explanations.D: You have given the lowest score in the highest group. We want the lowest score overall. What is the lowest stem number? What is the lowest leaf from that stem?

explanations.A: I think you have misread the key and the direction of the stem and leaf diagram. When interpreting the values we must write the stem number first.
explanations.B: Remember to look at the key! What place value do the stem numbers have?
explanations.C: I think you have misinterpreted the direction of the stem and leaf diagram. We always write our stem number first. Then look to the leaf.
explanations.D: The stem digit is 5 and the leaf digit is 6. The key tells us we can put these together to get 5.6

explanations.A: I think you have misread the key and the direction of the stem and leaf diagram. When interpreting the values we must write the stem number first.
explanations.B: The stem digit is 5 and the leaf digit is 1. The key tells us we can put these together to get 5.1
explanations.C: Remember to look at the key! What place value do the stem numbers have?
explanations.D: I think you have misinterpreted the direction of the stem and leaf diagram. We always write our stem number first. Then look to the leaf.
